video.title: Asynchronous JavaScript Course (Async/Await, Promises, Callbacks)
video.description:
Learn how to use Async/Await, Promises, and Callbacks in JavaScript.

✏️ Course from Joy Shaheb. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCHG7IJuST_BXJkne-0u0Xtw

📄 Article version: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/javascript-async-await-tutorial-learn-callbacks-promises-async-await-by-making-icecream/

⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:00:37) Asynchronous JS
⌨️ (0:01:48) Sync vs Async 
⌨️ (0:04:55) Examples ☝️ 
⌨️ (0:08:40) setTimeout function
⌨️ (0:13:21) callbacks w/examples
⌨️ (0:18:09) ice cream w/ callbacks 
⌨️ (0:42:02) Callback hell
⌨️ (0:43:32) Promises & promise cycle
⌨️ (0:54:22) Promise Chaining
⌨️ (1:03:27) error handling
⌨️ (1:05:37) finally handler 
⌨️ (1:07:26) Async/ Await 
⌨️ (1:09:42) try catch finally
⌨️ (1:15:46) Await keyword w/ example
⌨️ (1:25:22) ice cream w/ async/await

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Wong Voon jinq
👾 hexploitation
👾 Katia Moran
👾 BlckPhantom
👾 Nick Raker
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 Treehouse

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Vanderlei Roberto Moretto
topLevelComment.text:
I think there is a bug in the promises: the time passed for the order return to be set was an interval for the other/before the return because the resolve statement is inverted. if the times are great then it is visible! Because what actually happens is that the execution waits for that time passed in the return, and does not take the specified time.In a real case, an execution takes time to happen, not wait to happen.
A DB query does not wait for N time, but takes N time!
It's a silly detail, because it's a simulation, but it damages the logic of a Promise. 
Grateful

topLevelComment.author: Oliver Carvajal Gómez
topLevelComment.text:
I don't usually give negative feedback unless it's really necessary, which is the case here! This tuto is a complete joke for the simple fact that it doesn't require more than 5 minutes (at most) to explain what asyn/await or what a Promise is or how it works, even to a complete newbie!!! 

Asking to waste a long 90 minutes when a short 5 minutes would suffice seems to me a little too much to simply wipe it under the rug... 

My advice to newbies would be: if you want to learn fast, you need to go beyond following tutorials, and start reading documentation. This will help you evaluate when to follow a particular tuto or simply read the documentation of a particular language for a particular topic.



That been said, IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER, there's nothing against the teacher who seem to demonstrate nothing but good intention, nor against this channel since it offers a considerable amount of real good tutos in here. I thought it was worth sharing my feedback about this tutorial.

topLevelComment.text: So callback is basically recursion?

replies.author: Jayanta Samaddar
replies.text: No. Recursion is when a function calls itself (which can be confusing). Callback function is any other function called in the function. Both are callback functions but one is recursive the other is not.

Also can someone help me understand  'resolve( work() )" what infomation is passed here in work and why there is brackets after work. I will appreciate any reference in this regard. Sorry for my question

replies.author: Ihsan Nurul Iman
replies.text:
it's what we call as 'callback'. work() call the second argument's function. The second argument's function get its data from parameter that we pass in, which in this case an anymous function that returns console.log.

To learn more just google callback, there's a ton resource there.

topLevelComment.author: Magnetic Artmaster
topLevelComment.text:
Yes the Christmas tree is from hell: 

History of Christmas customs
Celebrating Jesus’ birthday: “The early Christians did not celebrate [Jesus’] birth because they considered the celebration of anyone’s birth to be a pagan custom.”—The World Book Encyclopedia.

December 25: There is no proof that Jesus was born on that date. Church leaders likely chose this date to coincide with pagan festivals held on or around the winter solstice.

Gift-giving, feasting, partying: The Encyclopedia Americana says: “Saturnalia, a Roman feast celebrated in mid-December, provided the model for many of the merry-making customs of Christmas. From this celebration, for example, were derived the elaborate feasting, the giving of gifts, and the burning of candles.” The Encyclopædia Britannica notes that “all work and business were suspended” during Saturnalia.

Christmas lights: According to The Encyclopedia of Religion, Europeans decorated their homes “with lights and evergreens of all kinds” to celebrate the winter solstice and to combat evil spirits.

Mistletoe, holly: “The Druids ascribed magical properties to the mistletoe in particular. The evergreen holly was worshiped as a promise of the sun’s return.”—The Encyclopedia Americana.

Christmas tree: “Tree worship, common among the pagan Europeans, survived after their conversion to Christianity.” One of the ways in which tree worship survived is in the custom of “placing a Yule tree at an entrance or inside the house in the midwinter holidays.”​—Encyclopædia Britannica.

https://www.jw.org/en/bible-teachings/questions/bible-about-christmas/

topLevelComment.author: Monsterlessons Academy
topLevelComment.text:
For people who want just a short answer: Always use async await and not promises with .then, .catch or callbacks. But of course you need to understand promises because async await is just a sugar around them. 
P.S. don't forget to always wrap async await code in try catch block to avoid "Unhandled promise rejection".
